articles.headline: U.S. and Colombia Near Trade Pact
articles.snippet: Colombia has agreed to do more to protect union leaders, which the administration hopes will help with Congress.
articles.abstract: Colombia has agreed to do more to protect union leaders, which the administration hopes will help with Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the announcement on Wednesday that it has extracted labor rights concessions from Colombia to advance a trade deal, the Obama administration is now two-thirds of the way toward meeting Republican demands that three languishing trade agreements be sent to Congress for approval.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: A Publicist Who Sees No Need to Duck Calls
articles.snippet: Kelly Bush, in your face and sure of herself, is helping to change the way P.R. is done among the top players in Hollywood.
articles.abstract: Kelly Bush, in your face and sure of herself, is helping to change the way P.R. is done among the top players in Hollywood.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Not many years ago, the top players in Hollywood publicity called back when they were good and ready. It was all about access — or the refusal to give it.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Small Cameras, Big Sensors
articles.snippet: Olympus and Panasonic introduce two Micro Four-Thirds cameras that offer fresh solutions to the small camera/big sensor problem.
articles.abstract: Olympus and Panasonic introduce two Micro Four-Thirds cameras that offer fresh solutions to the small camera/big sensor problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you want an easy puzzle, solve a Rubik’s Cube.

articles.headline: Japanese City’s Cry Resonates Around the World
articles.snippet: Mayor Katsunobu Sakurai issued a plea on YouTube for the world to help his city. He was not prepared for the response.
articles.abstract: Mayor Katsunobu Sakurai issued a plea on YouTube for the world to help his city. He was not prepared for the response.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINAMISOMA, Japan — It was a desperate plea for help, spoken into a small digital camcorder by the mayor of this seemingly forsaken city, and posted on the Internet like a bottle tossed into a digital sea.

articles.headline: Libyan Rebels Don’t Really Add Up to an Army
articles.snippet: Many of the fighters are brave, but by almost all measures by which a military might be assessed, they are a hapless bunch.
articles.abstract: Many of the fighters are brave, but by almost all measures by which a military might be assessed, they are a hapless bunch.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Late Monday afternoon, as Libyan rebels prepared another desperate attack on the eastern oil town of Brega, a young rebel raised his rocket-propelled grenade as if to fire. The town’s university, shimmering in the distance, was far beyond his weapon’s maximum range. An older rebel urged him to hold fire, telling him the weapon’s back-blast could do little more than reveal their position and draw a mortar attack.

articles.headline: Disabled, but Looking for Work
articles.snippet: The number of people collecting Social Security disability benefits is rising, and the agency’s Ticket to Work employment program has done little to ease the burden.
articles.abstract: The number of people collecting Social Security disability benefits is rising, and the agency’s Ticket to Work employment program has done little to ease the burden.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATESVILLE, Ark. — Christopher Howard suffers from herniated discs in his back, knee problems and hepatitis C. As a result, Social Security sends him $574 every month and will until he reaches retirement age — unless he can find a job.

articles.headline: Rifts Within Both Parties Test Leaders in Budget Fight
articles.snippet: President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner face challenges from adversaries as well as their own followers.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner face challenges from adversaries as well as their own followers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On one level, the budget showdown that continued to play out here on Wednesday is all about the balance of power between the two parties, a question of whether President Obama has regained his footing and can still control the direction of the country or whether Speaker John A. Boehner and the Republicans are now calling the shots.

articles.headline: Obama Is Set to Redo Team on War Policy
articles.snippet: Some key members of the national security team are departing, potentially revamping the entire dynamic of the next war council.
articles.abstract: Some key members of the national security team are departing, potentially revamping the entire dynamic of the next war council.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama assembled his first national security team, it was quickly dubbed, not always accurately, the “Team of Rivals.” Now that some of its key members are heading for the exits, the question is whether his next war council could be named the “Corps of Consensus.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Police Lesson: Social Network Tools Have Two Edges
articles.snippet: Facebook and Twitter can be valuable to law enforcement agencies, but careless postings get departments in trouble.
articles.abstract: Facebook and Twitter can be valuable to law enforcement agencies, but careless postings get departments in trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Officer Trey Economidy of the Albuquerque police now realizes that he should have thought harder before listing his occupation on his Facebook profile as “human waste disposal.”

articles.headline: Political Divide Poses Risks for Portugal in Bailout Talks
articles.snippet: Leaders in Lisbon will begin setting aside their domestic differences in order to negotiate with creditors.
articles.abstract: Leaders in Lisbon will begin setting aside their domestic differences in order to negotiate with creditors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON — Portugal’s request for an international bailout puts European leaders in the difficult position of drafting a package of austerity measures and financial aid that will survive the country’s caretaker government.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Stephen Castle
